summary: i see what you're saying and i agree, but i think terri probably does have ideas for a hypothetical s4. s3 will likely wrap up...
question: i see what you're saying and i agree, but i think terri probably does have ideas for a hypothetical s4. s3 will likely wrap up storylines in a satisfying way while leaving the ending open enough so that the show could continue if got renewed. s4 would essentially be starting w a blank slate. i feel like it would feel more like a miniseries or a spinoff, the storylines contained within that season. aging the characters up to high school opens the door for more i think.
answer:
I totally see what you mean. I’m sure Terri has had ideas for a season 4 at some point between the filming of season 3 and now and, to be fair, just because I don’t see where the story could go after season 3, doesn’t mean it couldn’t go anywhere. I’m by no means a screenwriter and, like I said, AM has tackled things I never thought it would/could and done them (mostly) with grace and care. That’s, in huge part, thanks to Terri fighting for the stories she wanted to tell. So, hypothetically, I’m sure Terri would continue doing that – but the wiggle room between what she’s already done and what she’d be allowed to do given another season seems very minimal at this point. 

Personally, I don’t think an episodic show like Andi Mack works if you try to start with a blank slate or a “spin-off” kind of thing because then the season becomes something of an unnecessary add-on instead of a natural continuation. When that kind of thing is done (and, more importantly, done well) with TV shows, it’s usually for the sole purpose of answering questions that the previous seasons didn’t answer. Like, the series finale of Veronica Mars was written when the writers had little to no idea it would be the series finale, and – because of that – there are so many unanswered questions and “Really? That’s it?” vibes to it, so they made the movie to smooth things over. I don’t imagine the (season 3) ending of Andi Mack will have that problem, so I don’t think we’d need the sort of “epilogue” that a season 4 might come off as. 

I guess it’s cynical to say, but it’s just my opinion that a season 4 couldn’t match (let alone surpass) the quality we’ve gotten thus far and, in that case, I don’t want it.

summary: Besides tyrus, what’s your favorite ship??
question: Besides tyrus, what’s your favorite ship??
answer:
Mufffy used to be my all time favorite ship. That kind of changed since the lack of scenes & Garren leaving. But he’s back, so maybe they’ll take second place eventually. (Also that changed as soon at T.J. came in lol)

Besides for Tyrus, my favorites definitely Ambi. It makes me sad that they’ll never be canon but ugh they’d be so cute together!

summary: I'm really tempted to send no. 3 but that's basically just last episode lmaoo so no. 11
question: I'm really tempted to send no. 3 but that's basically just last episode lmaoo so no. 11
answer:
Sorry it’s been a million years, but here it is! It’s a future AU and it’s pure self-indulgent, tooth rotting fluff. I hope you like it!

“Don’t you dare throw that snowba-, goddammit!” The ice was harsh against Cyrus’s cheek. “I’ll get you for that, Beck!”

Jonah laughed and sprinted behind the nearest tree. “I’d like to see you try, Goodman!”

“You can run, but you can’t hide!” Cyrus called out, before turning to the third member of their little trio. “Sergeant Ella, what do you say we engage in a sneak attack?”

Ella grinned, showing off dimples to match her father’s. “What did you have in mind?”

“You distract him, and I’ll attack.” Cyrus instructed his daughter.

Her dark eyes glinted in the pale winter sun, and she threw a salute.  “Aye, aye.”

“But first, we need ammo.” Cyrus added with a wink, and they set to work making snowballs. Before long, Ella had a mountain of snowballs, and her grin was wider than ever. It would never cease to amaze Cyrus how much she looked like Jonah when she smiled. Although, according to Jonah, she was all Cyrus, especially in the eyes, which he said were “big brown puppy dog eyes” that he never stood a chance against.

Either way, she was the best daughter anyone could ever ask for, and an even better partner in The Great Snowball War. The Snowball War was a tradition Cyrus and Jonah had had since high school. Every year, in the middle of February when they were going absolutely stir crazy with cabin fever, they’d go out to the park, and go at it. Some years, their friends would join them, but in more recent years, Ella had joined them. And boy was she a force to be reckoned with. She finished her pile of snowballs in record time, and headed for Jonah, hitting him in rapid fire. Of course, Jonah engaged, stepping away from his tree to fight back against Sergeant Ella. While Jonah was distracted, Cyrus scooped up a pile of the fresh fallen powder into his arms. He tiptoed up behind Jonah, lifted his arms, and dumped the whole pile on his head.

Jonah jumped nearly a foot in the air. “Cyrus! The snow is going down my shirt!”

Cyrus and Ella giggled and high-fived. “Well done, Sergeant! Enemy defeated!”

Jonah pouted and crossed his arms. “I’m freezing now, thanks to you.”

“Aw, honey,” Cyrus put an arm around his husband. “Do we need to go inside and get you some cocoa?”

Jonah nodded. “Yes, please.”

“And I thought the seven year old was the baby.” Cyrus rolled his eyes.

The trio made their way towards the entrance of the park, Cyrus and Jonah holding hands, and Ella running ahead of them. Jonah stopped for a moment,  and Cyrus was about to ask if something was wrong, when Jonah dropped his hand and shoved him into a nearby snow bank.

“Revenge!” Jonah shouted, pumping his fist in the air.

“Seriously?” Cyrus struggled to pull himself out of the slush, to know avail. “I can’t get up. Help?” He reached his hand out towards Jonah.

“Sure,” Jonah took Cyrus’s hand.

“Oh, you beautiful, trusting idiot.” Cyrus tightened his grip and yanked Jonah into the snow bank beside him. “I can’t believe you fell for that.”

Ella giggled. “You look funny like that.”

“I can’t believe our seven year old daughter is the only one who survived this snowball fight unscathed,” Jonah laughed.

“We had fun, though,” Cyrus offered.

“True.” Jonah pulled himself out of the snow bank. “And I don’t think we’re done yet.” He scooped up a handful of snow and pressed into a ball. He tossed it at Ella, hitting her torso. She immediately fell to the ground in dramatic fashion.

“Oh, I’ve been hit! I’ve been hit!” She called out, her hands clutching her side where the snowball had landed.

“Yeah,” Jonah pulled Cyrus out of the snow bank. “She’s definitely your daughter.”

Cyrus huffed, and tossed some loose snow his husband’s way.

“Hey!” Jonah whined, wiping the snow from his cheek. “That’s just rude.”

Cyrus shrugged and started forming more snowballs. Eventually, they would stumble back home, cold and wet, to have that hot cocoa. Jonah’s mug would be brimming with mini marshmallows, and Ella would fall asleep on the couch.

But this war wasn’t over yet.

“Seriously?” Cyrus struggled to pull himself out of the slush, to know avail. “I can’t get up. Help?” He reached his hand out towards Jonah.

“Sure,” Jonah took Cyrus’s hand.

“Oh, you beautiful, trusting idiot.” Cyrus tightened his grip and yanked Jonah into the snow bank beside him. “I can’t believe you fell for that.”

Ella giggled. “You look funny like that.”

“I can’t believe our seven year old daughter is the only one who survived this snowball fight unscathed,” Jonah laughed.

“We had fun, though,” Cyrus offered.

“True.” Jonah pulled himself out of the snow bank. “And I don’t think we’re done yet.” He scooped up a handful of snow and pressed into a ball. He tossed it at Ella, hitting her torso. She immediately fell to the ground in dramatic fashion.

“Oh, I’ve been hit! I’ve been hit!” She called out, her hands clutching her side where the snowball had landed.

“Yeah,” Jonah pulled Cyrus out of the snow bank. “She’s definitely your daughter.”

Cyrus huffed, and tossed some loose snow his husband’s way.

“Hey!” Jonah whined, wiping the snow from his cheek. “That’s just rude.”

Cyrus shrugged and started forming more snowballs. Eventually, they would stumble back home, cold and wet, to have that hot cocoa. Jonah’s mug would be brimming with mini marshmallows, and Ella would fall asleep on the couch.

But this war wasn’t over yet.
trail.content_abstract:
Sorry it’s been a million years, but here it is! It’s a future AU and it’s pure self-indulgent, tooth rotting fluff. I hope you like it!

“Don’t you dare throw that snowba-, goddammit!” The ice was harsh against Cyrus’s cheek. “I’ll get you for that, Beck!”

Jonah laughed and sprinted behind the nearest tree. “I’d like to see you try, Goodman!”

“You can run, but you can’t hide!” Cyrus called out, before turning to the third member of their little trio. “Sergeant Ella, what do you say we engage in a sneak attack?”

Ella grinned, showing off dimples to match her father’s. “What did you have in mind?”

tags: throwing some thoughts into the abyss happy thursday
summary: I might get some negativity for this, but just throwing my thoughts out into the void here.  Not to get too “we living in a...
body:
I might get some negativity for this, but just throwing my thoughts out into the void here. 

Not to get too “we living in a society” on y’all, but we’re so afraid of endings. The reason we live in an era of reboots, remakes, sequels and shows continuing passed their prime is because, yes, studios are running out of ideas and repackaging old ones, but more so because they know we’ll buy into it. We latch onto familiarity so fast.

You want to explore your favorite story in a new way (and even if you don’t, you’ll watch it just to see how it compares to the original). You want to see what your favorite characters are up to…none of us want the stories we love and the characters that tell them to end.

The same goes for Andi Mack. I know we’ve all addressed, at one point or another, that a season 4 is very unlikely and as much as I might go full sad boy hours™ and cry into my pillow during the season 3 finale, that might be a good thing. 

I’m so grateful for Terri, the writers, the actors – everyone who works on Andi Mack. Whenever I thought they would never, they did. It’s a big reason why I tried to stop posting my predictions – because I’m continuously out-smarted by this show and those posts age so poorly. So maybe I’m wrong in saying this, but given the satisfying ending to season 3 that I expect to get: where can they go from here? 

Tyrus canoning? A historic moment for children’s television that could be, at best, moved to the background in a potential season 4 and at worst, never shown or rarely mentioned again.

Jandi drama? Here we go again. You know Disney’s #1 ship isn’t going a whole ‘nother season without more back-and-fourth drama.

They would have to backtrack too much of the closure they’re (likely) giving us in the coming episodes. Even if they were able to successfully backtrack just enough to keep the story going, could they ever really top Cyrus saying he’s gay on screen? Or the gun safety storyline? Or Disney Channel’s first gay relationship? 

I think we need to destroy the idea that good media is the kind that doesn’t end. Some goodbyes are harder than others, but sometimes it’s better to say goodbye to a good thing instead of holding onto it until you don’t like it anymore.

After all, “You either die a hero or you live long enough to see yourself become the villain.” *

* Did I just quote The Dark Knight? Yep, this post is one big rant-y mess and I’m sorry.

summary: To the people who sent me kissing prompts today:
body:
To the people who sent me kissing prompts today:

I am writing some other things currently, but I will get to your prompts asap! I’m hoping to start writing them when I go to bed tonight, as a way to stay up to watch Andi Mack! I will hopefully have at least half of them done by this weekend!

To everyone else:

I will be posting the epilogue of Touch-Starved tonight, and I will be posting another oneshot! Look out for that!

(Also I have some multi-chapter fics in the works, and those should be posted sooner than you think!)

summary: Didn’t Austin & Ally get a 4th season bc of a Twitter campaign (somewhat led by Calum and Raini)? I’m not sure how much...
question: Didn’t Austin & Ally get a 4th season bc of a Twitter campaign (somewhat led by Calum and Raini)? I’m not sure how much influence they really had tho, maybe Disney just wanted to keep Ross around. More recently, GMW’s campaign was crazy b4&after being cancelled & Disney was still firm in their decision to let the show go. Bottom line is: I don’t think the fact that AM isn’t on a streaming service really matters. Disney will make a decision based on who knows what & they’ll be stubborn as hell.
answer:
I don’t know much about the renewal of Austin & Ally because that was during the phase of my life where I stopped watching Disney Channel. The campaigning has very little to do with chances of renewal, as we saw with Girl Meets World… but the fact that it’s not on a streaming service has absolutely everything to do with it. Streaming services are most of the reason that ratings are declining on Disney Channel and other children’s networks. 

Most of the parents I know who are in their 20s and 30s and who have kids in Disney Channel’s target demographic don’t pay for cable, and even if they do - it’s more convenient for them to get on Netflix and turn on an entire season of cartoons or something to keep their children busy longer rather than having to flip through channels and keep an eye on what they are watching.  More and more people are cutting their cable subscriptions and relying on services like Netflix, Hulu, etc. for their TV fix and Disney is obviously aware of that, hence Disney+.

It’s just not very helpful to anyone in terms of the series that already exist on Disney Channel. But had a service like Disney+ existed for the past few years, or had the seasons been available to stream in full on Netflix - all of our campaigning for the last two years would have resulted in more viewers one way or another, meaning more profit for Disney, meaning increased chance of renewal. Netflix kind of has a stubborn “do whatever the fuck they want” attitude about renewals and cancellations too so I definitely don’t think they would have been our saviors or anything (like I’ve always said - Andi Mack HAS to be a children’s show with Disney show to work, otherwise it’s not that groundbreaking) but availability is key in the streaming age, and unfortunately Andi Mack just hasn’t been made readily available for all of the people who would love to watch and support it.
